posts.name: Hunter
posts.cooked:
Hello, I am looking for some advice on how to make a instructional website for my team (with hope to make it available for all of FIRST ). I want it to have basics with CAD, Build, Manufacturing, and also have Calculators for CAD or links to sites that already exist like ReCalc.

I was wondering if anyone knows of resources/websites that I can use to make this a possible thing. I want to make it stay as a free domain so that anyone can access this as a permeant resource. If this could have a minimum amount of coding that I would do on my end that would also be great as I am trying to do this as a senior project that I can leave for my team. I already looked into things like Wix or SquareSpace but I don’t know how those would pan out.

Thank you in advance for any help, It is greatly appreicated.

posts.name: Cole Hunt
posts.cooked: Depending on how comfortable you are with programming you could look into hosting a Docusaurus site on your teams GitHub (If you use one for code management). You should be able to host a GitHub Page for free from your GitHub account.

link_counts.title: Build optimized websites quickly, focus on your content | Docusaurus
GitHub Pages | Websites for you and your projects, hosted directly from your GitHub repository. Just edit, push, and your changes are live.

posts.name: Vivi S
posts.cooked:
If you’re not into programming too much and just want something easily customizable, Wix or SquareSpace is probably the way to go.

I’ve had experience using both in the past (especially for FIRST teams) and it’s a great starter point. The UI is easy to navigate and understand, and there are also tons of tutorials on how to do different things online. Plus… they’re free! However, you don’t have full control over your domain (or something like that) unless you pay, so that is a bit of a con.

Wish you luck!

posts.name: Hunter
posts.cooked: Alright, Thanks, I am not very comfortable with coding and my knowledge is very limited but I do have some very good mentors that would be happy to help

posts.name: Cole Hunt
posts.cooked:
Setting it up is probably the trickiest part, but once you get a base framework its just as simple as adding a Markdown file for each new page of content. I am not as familiar with site design or web dev, but AI has been very helpful to get me up to speed. You can check out kinda our basic document site here . (I only really have some basic software docs as of right now, there is another mentor working on design/fab, but he hasn’t published yet)

Edit: I have been using this as a reference and starting point. They use it more as a public facing site, but have documentation available for students.

posts.name: Nolan Barker
posts.cooked:
For building a documentation-style website that needs no backend , I don’t think you’d be making a mistake using Sphinx with GitHub Pages and Actions.

Features:

You write your docs in a language similar to markdown, but with more powers: RST, or reStructured Text.

You can pick from a lot of nice visual themes which pretty much “just work” (I really like sphinxawesome-theme ).

You can setup build actions through GitHub pages to automatically rebuild your documentation when you push updates to the main branch.

You can setup GitHub pages, which gives you a free domain ( username.github.io/reponame ) and then your site is live forever . You’ll also have the option in the future to switch to a custom domain if you decide to pay for it - but this is completely optional.

Configuration file ( conf.py ) is in Python, which is a really easy language to learn and mess with, especially for this use case. You don’t have to do much configuration once you get started, but there’s a lot you can do if you really want.

There’s lots of documentation out there to use this tool. I looked at the source code for the WPILib docs, for example, when trying to learn how to use Sphinx.

posts.name: Dan Peled
posts.cooked: From my experience something like mkdocs or readthedocs is very intuitive to use, even for non software people, it’s basically just writing Markdown code which is very easy to understand
